title: Antisymmetric relation
summary: In mathematics, a binary relation R {\displaystyle R} on a set X {\displaystyle X} is antisymmetric if there is no pair of distinct elements of X {\displaystyle X} each of which is related by R {\displaystyle R} to the other. More formally, R {\displaystyle R} is antisymmetric precisely if for all a , b âˆˆ X , {\displaystyle a,b\in X,}
